bug.short_desc: master loses track of the real number of workers

long_desc.thetext:
Master loses the track of the real number of workers it has, due to segfaults in certain states. This can lead to worker starvation (master doesn't fork a new one because it thinks there are available workers).
The attached patch, based on a patch to 2.1.3 by the fastmail.fm crew takes care of this issue, tracking workers by pid.
Created an attachment (id=35) track workers by pid and sigchld
this patch is a bit improved over the one I sent to the cyrus ML, as it does not bitch to syslog about EVENTS children (which obviously are not in the workers list).
Created an attachment (id=39) New version of child pidfile control, using a morgue to avoid race condition
Created an attachment (id=43) fix typo in pidmorgue patch (Jaska Kivel� <jk@almamedia.fi>)

So far this has been the most compelling argument to me:
Henrique de Moraes Holschuh wrote:
>Still, I am seriously thinking about doing something to any unknown children >master notices (with proper LOG_ERR logging, of course) because said >children is messaging it. Such a thing (unknown children) can only happen >if either the underlying OS is messed up, or if we have a bug or memory >corruption in the linked list, AFAIK. > > Actually this can happen. The CHLD signal handler can run before master gets to process the child's message. We see this happen quite regularly on a busy server.
-Jeremy Howard

Argh, the above is referring to the patch, not to the current method.
The problem with going back through old threads.
the "morgue" is designed to avoid the race condition that Jeremy mentions.

ok, rob's activity got me to look at the patch again.
i have several issues besides the "i don't understand why this is necessary" problem.
processes are added to the morgue when they die. they're removed from the morgue on first receipt of a message after their death. what if a process never gets a message after it dies? when does it leave the morgue? what if a process sends several messages after it's death?

Children can indeed be forgotten in the morgue. I suppose if this is the only problem with the patch, we could add a timestamp and a morgue janitor. Looks like a good idea anyway, if only to log somewhere that such things are happening...
The multiple messages question is tricky. We won't err the child counter, but spill a warning to the syslog for every message after the first. I've never seen this happen, btw.

Here's a design change to the morgue that I will start coding soon. It should fix all issues.
1. children are added to the morgue when they die. Deaths are timestamped in their "thombstones", for accounting purposes. we check to make sure there is not already an empty thomb for a child (see (2)) 2. messages to dead children get noted in the thombstone, but not acted upon. messages to unknown dead children create an empty thomb, also timestamped. syslog (debug, not an error) if in verbose mode any empty thomb creations. 3. a morgue janitor does periodic runs and: 3a. lets any dead corpses with messages older than N cleanup runs rest in peace (remove from morgue list) 3b. syslogs notices of any messages received from ghosts (unknown children) older than N cleanup runs, and gets rid of the empty thombs 3c. syslog debug notices for any duplicated messages received from properly dead children, and clean these up like in (3a)
Seems safe, simple enough, and no-race-prone way to deal with the problem to me. Any comments before I start coding?
The janitor periodic runs need to be tunable (command line, with a one-second, N=1 default), since busy servers need them more often. Maybe they could also be triggered by a too-many-hash-colisions scenario in the morgue. They happen after the periodic SNMP data gathering runs.
I am planning to use a hash table to avoid too much of a performance impact, at the cost of sligher bigger memory usage on master (which is not critical, since there is only one copy of master anyway).
As for why the morgue is needed, well, the current way simply does not work in the following scenarios:
(1). children die before their messages arrive (busy servers) (2). children die due to bugs, process limits, and whatnot, and thus never send messages, and master eventually deadlocks.
(1) is a design bug that needs fixing IMHO, and not taking (2) into account is not a good idea on production servers, either.

Created an attachment (id=135) fix messaging after fork failure
Just noticed that this nearly-never used codepath was broken. It causes no bad consequences other than syslogged complains, though.
last patch is buggy. fix the msg.service_pid = p; to msg.service_pid = getpid();

Created an attachment (id=146) new "mogue" strategy: service states and janitor
This patch should implement a simple version of a janitor-based child control. There is no morgue anymore. Instead, we store the state of the service child in the child table. Also, we account for "deep pipes" (where the messages arrive later than children death signals are processed), and messages arriving from non-registered children.
In teory, children do not need to message master if they are going to exit (if this patch is applied).
Also, the janitor can be much more intelligent. The version in the patch is just the simplest one I could come up with, for testing.
This patch addresses the following problems in the current CVS code for 2.1:
1. Children die for whatever reason without messaging master 2. Children die before their messages reach master 3. Messages reach master before children are "registered"

based on my brief reading, i think this patch is substantially better.
neither (2) or (3) is a concern for the 2.1 master, since messages do not contain PID information and are not correlated to entries in ctable[]. (1) is clearly a concern and what this bug is about.
i will try to do a more thorough review later.

Created an attachment (id=156) frequency-based janitor strategy
This patch implements the service states and janitor, and updates the janitor strategy to something that can actually be used on production:
1. Make sure to run every 10s or so (using a periodic event and waking master up) 2. Incremental janitor runs: the janitor can sweep just a small part of the ctable hash table, and continue where it left off in the next sweep. 3. simple frequency-based control: by default, do one full hash-table sweep per second, can be adjusted for higher frequencies using -j command line switch (added to master and manpage).
It should be good enough a default for slow and medium sites. It wakes up master only every 10s during inactivity periods, and it spreads the sweeping cost over multiple calls during peak periods (while it is called far more often).
The default frequency of one sweep per second, with the default hash table size of 10000 buckets should handle about 10000 forks per second without increasing hash-table colisions too much. I didn't stress-test it to profile resource usage on the janitor at high load, though.
What the janitor approach does cause is an increase in the memory usage of master, since it will only reclaim child entries after the janitor notices them. This is actually the reason I foresee for someone to try increasing the janitor frequency... to reclaim child entries faster.
I used the following constants in the code: 1. clean up children no sooner than 1s (and no later than 2s) after their deaths. This assumes this delay is enough to avoid most warnings due to lost signals (i.e. that signals will get delivered within 2s). It is not a problem if they get delayed more than 2s, but master will complain in the syslog.
That's about enough for my modest needs, I would need input from high-load sites to improve things for them as well.
This is related to Bug 1254.

Created an attachment (id=220) Rob's version of this patch
Brief testing revealed one or two problems with this:
- master was still treating the message as an int and not as a struct - there was a race caused by the SERVICE_STATE_INIT value, which I just changed to use SERVICE_STATE_READY (which is the current behavior--though I guess ideally we would want to differentiate the two states)
Henrique, does this patch still look sane to you?
(From update of attachment 220) Note that the new patch is against 2.2

Well, I can't find where msg was still being treated as an int instead of a struct... it might be a real problem, or just a stupid mistake when I extracted the patch from my tree. I'd appreciate if you pointed it out, so that I can fix it in the code I have in Debian :-)
Also, the INIT race is not clear to me right now. I will study it more, and see if I discover where the race is. I do remember I added the two states (INIT and READY) to avoid something, so I really want to revisit this issue. Could you describe the race you found?
I will reply as soon as I have studied the issue again, which should not take too much time.
Thanks for looking into this issue, Rob!
Found the int thing. As usual, I had forgotten about service-thread.c. I am still looking at the race condition, but have not found it yet.

Glad you found the int thing ;)
The race was pretty obvious with ptloader in 2.2, and I suspect it affects fud as well. However, here's where I think it is:
a new service is created, and its state is set to SERVICE_STATE_INIT. Master finishes creating all the services and starts looking at its ready_workers counters. If the proceses take a long time to start up, it will start a second one, and a third. This isn't a problem with imapd (where we'll just have a bunch of extras that will eventually die off, but it is a problem for services we only want one of (fud, ptloader).
I also have concerns about the fact that service.c never sends an AVAILABLE message once it is ready for the first connection -- it has a bunch of places where it can send UNAVAILABLE (before service_init is called) but it will accept its first connection before ever sending AVAILABLE. Obviously this isn't an issue in my patch but if my patch is incorrect, this issue needs to be solved as well.
I see. Yep, these are problems we need fixed alright. I will work on doing so. It should be doable :-)

OK, I started documenting what the code does, and I noticed service-thread never sends any AVAILABLE OR UNAVAILABLE messages. If service.c not sending an initial AVAILABLE worries you, shouldn't that mean service-thread is completely off-track as well?
If the idea behind service-thread is that every instance of it is actually "an infinite number of workers", then wouldn't we be better off creating new message types for it, and decoupling it from the normal service.c messaging scheme?

I didn't actually look at mupdate in my testing (the only service-thread client), but yes, service-thread services are basicly 'infinite' numbers of workers.
Its not entirely clear what messages service-thread processes should send. Probably CONNECTION (and if we *must* differentiate between INIT and READY, something to signal READY).
Note that we only need to send an initial AVAILABLE in service.c if we are differentiating between INIT and READY. Otherwise we can just assume a service that is in the INIT state will be ready soon enough that it isn't a real issue.

Ok, I've got the state diagrams for both your and my code (and guess what, both are buggy in corner conditions :-P). I am still working on a proper state diagram and implementation that is clean from the ground-up.
5 States are useful *IF* we are afraid of children hanging before they send a message to master, but since it is quite unlikely that starting other children in this case will be of any help... 4 states it is (unless I find some race that requires a fifth state).
That means the first "available" message must be implied. Thus, service.c is correct. A first AVAILABLE message can only be sent IF we implement the INIT state, and change master accordinly to not start spawining children like mad while it waits them to become ready.
A new message for service-thread is a good idea. CONNECTION_MULTI, that does no changes to readyworkers. Thus, service-thread can send UNAVAILABLE (if it is unwilling to service more connections), AVAILABLE (to resume from the former state), CONNECTION_MULTI (it is going to accept more connections while handling the current one). We could make it work with CONNECTION as well (send UNAVAILABLE + CONNECTION if this is the last concurrent connection it will serve for a while), but CONNECTION_MULTI is easy to implement, and easier to use.
